page.title: 08Natural History
page.content: Within the total forest area of 6,000 acres there are four main varieties of {trees:}oak, hornbeam, beech and birch. It was a{Royal Forest}until 1882 when there were many deer in it. But now with the pressure of the modern society on it the few surviving{red {deer}have to be protected in special areas. Many years ago rich landowners tried to{enclose}large areas of the forest for themselves. This meant that the local people could not lop the trees for firewood. Many people fought against this, including Thomas Willingale. The trees could be lopped at head height{(pollarding)}or at ground level{(coppicing). There are many{ponds}within the forest, the largest of which is Connaught Waters named after Lord Connaught, a nephew of Queen Victoria.
